result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th or 6th) and Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Eugene A. Butteris was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Eugene A. Butteris was found guilty of Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Case called at 11:23 am [Clerk SH]
Defendant Eugene A. Butteris in court with Attorney Elizabeth F Svehlek. ADA Jeffrey Martin Shock appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Constitutional rights reviewed; maximum penalties recited; plea of "No Contest" entered on Counts #1 & #3; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; Court finds the plea has been entered freely, voluntarily, intelligently and accepts the plea, finds the Defendant  guilty, and orders JOC entered.
On Motion of the State, the Court reads-in and dismisses Count #2
Upon questioning of the Court, Counsel realized that defense and State have different page 2 of CCS
ADA Shock provides correct page two of CCS to the Court and to Atty Svehlek

On Count #1, the Court sentences Mr. Butteris to 4 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 2 years and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 2 years. This sentence is to commence consecutive to any previously imposed sentence or forthwith

The Court finds that the Defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program (Boot Camp) and IS eligible for the Substance Abuse Program. 
The Court gives 2 days credit for time already served.

The Court orders as conditions of Extended Supervision:
--To pay a fine of $3000 + costs, assessments, fees and surcharges
--To pay $56.74 blood testing surcharge (Jefferson PD)
--To submit DNA Sample upon demand & pay surcharge
--Absolute sobriety
--No possession or consumption of alcohol or illegal drugs
--No operation of a motor vehicle without a valid DL and Agent Approval
--No acts/threats of violence
--No presence in bars, taverns or liquor stores
--To undergo any assessment, treatment or counseling as per Agent

Conditions Not of Extended Supervision:
--Revocation of drivers license for 36 months
--County alcohol/drug assessment ordered
--Victim impact panel attendance
--Ignition Interlock Device requirement/restrictions for:36 months
--6 demerit points assessed

Felony Firearm and Voting-rights prohibitions/warnings given
Explanation of Determinate Sentence form given to the Defendantent

On Count #3, the Court sentences the Defendant:
--serve 6 months County Jail, with Huber/Work-Release privileges; to commence concurrent to Count #1, to be served in prison system
--to pay costs of $443; to be converted to civil judgment

Recess: 11:46 am
Plea/sentencing hearing on June 2, 2016 at 10:45 am.

Case called at 1:25 pm [Clerk SH] (Case was scheduled for FSSC & MH)
Defendant Eugene A. Butteris in court with Attorney Elizabeth F Svehlek. DA Susan Victoria Happ appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Atty Svehlek informs the Court that they have received criminal case settlement from the State, which Mr. Butteris wishes to accept; however are not yet prepared to accept that offer yet, presents basis. Requests adjournment to Friday for plea/sentencing. 
Court informs parties that It can only adjourn to Thursday due to other cases scheduled for trial and are out of the office on Friday.
DA Happ presents no objection to adjournment of plea/sentencing to Thursday
Recess: 1:29 pm

Case called at 2:18 pm [mo]
Defendant Eugene A. Butteris appears via videoconferencing from the Jefferson County Jail, in custody, with Attorney Elizabeth Svehlek (PD will appoint counsel).  Public Service Special Prosecutor, Melanie Flint appears for the State of Wisconsin.  

Atty. Svehlek indicates that Mr. Butteris IS eligible for PD representation

On agreement of counsel, the Court finds that the videoconferencing system is sight and sound sufficient. 

Service of Complaint admitted, reading waived, the charge and maximum penalties are recited. 
Preliminary Hearing time limits are waived by both parties.

The Court requires a $10,000  signature bond, with conditions:
-  No alcohol possession or ingestion. 
-  No presence in bars, taverns, liquor stores. 
-  No operation of a motor vehicle without a valid drivers license.
-  The Defendant is to report and comply with SCRAM alcohol monitoring program as administered by Wisconsin Community Services.  The Court orders the defendant to SCRAM monitoring through WCS, with the consideration of Remote Breath as an alternative only when WCS verifies that a defendant's work environment or health condition prohibits the SCRAM bracelet.

The Defendant is to comply with all SCRAM Program conditions of participation including payment of program costs and fees.  **If in custody, release on SCRAM only.**

recess 2:22  pm. 


NEXT: (1) Pretrial Conference on 11/4/15 at 10:00am   (2) Status Conference on 12/29/15 at 8:30am
